Research Paper High-performance CuMgAl catalysts derived from hydrotalcite for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol: Effects of Cu-MgO interaction Haoran Liu Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation a Wenbin Huang Investigation Data curation a Zhiqing Yu Software Investigation b Xiaohan Wang Methodology c Yijing Jia Data curation a Meng Huang Methodology a Han Yang Formal analysis a Rongrong Li Methodology a Qiang Wei Supervision Resources a Yasong Zhou Supervision Resources a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum Beijing 102249 PR China aState Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Beijing 102249, PR China b College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Tianjin University of Science and Technology, Tianjin 300457, PR China College of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Tianjin University of Science and Technology Tianjin 300457 PR China bCollege of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Tianjin University of Science and Technology, Tianjin 300457, PR China c Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan, Shanxi 030001, PR China Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China cInstitute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan, Shanxi 030001, PR China ⁎ Correspoinding author. Using the coprecipitation approach, the CuMgAl catalysts with varying Cu loadings (x-CMA, x = 4, 6, 8, 10, 12 wt.%) were created from hydrotalcite precursors and used in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol process. In this work, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, TEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, H2-TPD, XPS, and in situ DRIFTS characterization techniques were used to examine the structure and surface characteristics of x-CMA catalysts. The results demonstrated that an appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO was formed when the Cu loading was 10 wt%, which was conducive to the generation of more Cu-MgO interfaces, boosting the adsorption of CO2. The appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO also facilitates the production of Cu0, enhancing the dissociation of H2. The conversion of CO3 * and HCO3 * to HCOO * has been sped up by advancements in CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation, which made the subsequent conversion to CH3OH easier. It also be found that 10-CMA obtained by the coprecipitation approach exhibited more Cu-MgO interfaces than 10-C/MA prepared by the impregnation method. At 2.5 MPa and 240 °C, the 10-CMA catalyst had the maximum STYCH3OH of 408.6 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h −1 with the XCO2 of 14.1 % and SCH 3 OH of 93.9 %. The findings presented in this work may offer a fresh perspective on how to create high-efficiency catalysts that hydrogenate CO2 into methanol. Graphic abstract The reaction pathway comparison for carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol on the x-CMA catalyst before and after the optimization of Cu-MgO interaction Image, graphical abstract Keywords CuMgAl catalysts Hydrotalcite CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Cu-MgO interaction Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Intriduction In recent decades, excessive carbon dioxide emission has become a serious problem leading to global climate change, causing great harm to human survival [1–3]. One strategy to reduce CO2 emissions and maximize its use is to convert CO2 into methanol using green hydrogen, a concept that has garnered a lot of interest from academics lately [4–7]. Methanol is a crucial chemical raw ingredient that is used to make a variety of high-value compounds, including ethylene, high-octane gasoline, and fuel additives [8–10]. The use of Cu-based catalysts for the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to methanol has been extensively studied. Most academics agree that very inexpensive copper-based catalysts are good options for hydrogenating carbon dioxide into methanol [11–13]. However, Cu-based catalysts still have the disadvantages of low activity and low stability [14–16], so it is crucial to develop highly active and stable Cu-based catalysts. Recently, Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have garnered great attention due to their unique layered structure and physicochemical features [17,18]. The classical formula of LDHs is [ M 1 − x 2 + M x 3 + ( O H ) 2 ] z + • [ A z n n − • m H 2 O ] z − , in which M2+and M3+represent binary and trivalent cations, respectively [19]. The benefits of composite oxides made from LDHs include strong basicity, large specific surface area, synergistic impact between elements, uniform dispersion of M2+ and M3+ at the atomic level, and great anti-sintering stability, which are extensively employed in the field of carbon dioxide hydrogenation [20–22]. A range of excellent CuZnAlZr catalysts was synthesized from LDH precursors, demonstrating the benefits of the catalysts with LDH as precursors in carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol [23–25]. The hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to methanol was carried out using the Cu/MgO/Al2O3 mixed oxide catalyst, which was synthesized using CuMgAl hydrotalcite as the precursor [26]. Small Cu nanoparticles with a restricted distribution are present in the catalyst (2cnm). This copper-based catalyst exhibits extraordinary activity, which is explained by the lattice reconfiguration linked to the water-promoted "HT memory effect" that enhances Cu+ ion stability in reaction conditions. Fernández-Villanueva et al. found that the isolated Cu+ species doped on the oxide surface of Cu-MgO-Al2O3 mixed oxide was the active sites in the process of carbon dioxide hydrogenation, thus stabilizing the key intermediates in the process of methanol synthesis [27]. For supported catalysts, metal-support interaction (MSI) is crucial. Significant variations in catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability are caused by metal dispersion, oxygen vacancy, and electron transfer, all of which are influenced by MSI. In order to better understand the MSI, many scholars have conducted a number of studies in recent years on the structure-performance connections, active site identification, and reaction processes [28–31]. By altering the precipitation sequence and Cu/Zr molar ratio of the precursor in the oxalate precipitation process, the interfacial structure of Cu/ZrO2 catalyst may be modified. As the Cu/Zr ratio increases, a high catalytic performance Cu-ZrO2 inverse interface was produced [32]. A straightforward method for creating ZnFe2O4 spinel-supported Cu catalysts with adjustable Cu nanoparticle sizes for carbon dioxide hydrogenation to methanol was described by Liu et al. [33]. The active site for accelerating the production of methanol was the Cu-ZnO interface. According to Chen et al. [34], the Cu-LaOx interface created by widely distributed Cu nanoparticles loaded on a La-modified SBA-15 carrier showed enhanced stability and a high methanol selectivity of up to 81.2 %. Through DFT calculation, Sharma et al. [35] found that the Cu-TiO2 interface on the smaller Cu cluster provided a low barrier pathway for CO2 activation through COOH intermediates, and stabilized CO and HCO, which was conducive to the formation of methanol. Sharma et al. [36] reported that Cu/MgO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had strong metal-support interaction and good anti-agglomeration performance. On the surface of Cu13/MgO(100), HCOO* intermediates were more stable than COOH* intermediates. Sharma et al. [37] also found that the adsorption capacity of CO2 on the Cu-MgO interface was stronger than that on the Cu-ZnO interface. Cao et al. identified the MgO/Cu interface to be a highly active site through density functional theory (DFT) calculations and microdynamic modeling and proposed a new lattices-oxygen reaction mechanism for methanol formation at the interface [38]. In this study, the coprecipitation approach was used to prepare a range of x-CMA catalysts obtained from hydrotalcite precursors with varying Cu loadings. The XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, TEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, H2-TPD, XPS, and in situ DRIFTS techniques were used to ascertain the structure and surface characteristics of the x-CMA catalysts. It was thoroughly investigated how the Cu-MgO interaction affected the adsorption, activation, and conversion of carbon dioxide during it was hydrogenated into methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Synthesis of CuMgAl. According to literature reports, using an enhanced coprecipitation technique, CuMgAl catalysts produced from hydrotalcite with varying Cu loading were created [39]. Metal salt solution A consisted of dissolving a certain amount of Cu, Mg, Al nitrate in 100 mL deionized water (Mg/Al molar ratio=3). 100 mL of sodium Na2CO3 (0.15 M) made up solution B. To obtain the LDH precursor, the solution A was dropped into solution B accompanied by vigorous agitation at 65 ° C. An alkali solution of NaOH (1.0 M) was used to modify the pH during precipitation, which was continuously measured at 10.0 ± 0.5 using a pH electrode. After that, the suspension was aged for five hours at 65 °C. Following filtering, the precipitate was cleaned with pH=7 deionized water and dried for 12 h at 100 °C. The resulting solids were the progenitors of the CuMgAl catalysts with hydrotalcite structure. The precursors were crushed into a fine powder and burned in a muffle furnace utilizing static air for five hours at 500 °C ramping at a rate of 2 °C per minute. After being extruded into a circular sheet, the resultant material was crushed and sieved into particles with apertures as small as 20 to 40 mesh. The synthesized catalysts are noted as x-CMA, where x (x = 4, 6, 8, 10, 12 wt. %) representes the Cu content of the catalyst. In addition, MA represented the sample without Cu, and the preparation method was consistent with CMA. Meanwhile, 10-Cu/MgAl catalyst with MA as support was also produced by a wet impregnation approach and was recorded as 10-C/MA. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Using Rigaku SmartLab SE photoelectron spectrometer with Cu K α radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) to obtain the diffraction characteristics of the prepared material. At a scanning rate of 10 °C/min, XRD patterns were collected for two hours at values ranging from 5 ° to 90 ° The N2 adsorption-desorption method was used to obtain the pore structure characteristics of the synthesized materials. The synthesized samples were treated for 4 h at 300 °C in a Beishide 3H-2000PS2 physical adsorption instrument. They were then cooled to −196 °C for N2 adsorption and desorption experiments, where the changes in N2 adsorption and desorption with pressure were noted. The pore structure characteristics was obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption method: the synthesized samples were treated at 300 °C vacua for 4 h by Beishide 3H-2000PS2 physical adsorption instrument, and then cooled to −196 °C for N2 adsorption and desorption experiments, and the changes of N2 adsorption and desorption with pressure were recorded. The surface area and aperture data are calculated by the BET and BJH formulas respectively. The FEI Tecnai G2 F30 was used for TEM detection. Its X-ray energy spectrum (EDX) had a voltage of 210 kV and a resolution of 0.14 nanometers. Prior to TEM detection, the catalyst was reduced by H2, the sample was dissolved in anhydrous ethanol, and it was ultrasonically scanned for 20 min. Then the sample was dropped onto a nickel net coated with a carbon film, which was thoroughly dried for testing. The Hitachi SU8010 SEM, operating at 5 kV, was used to examine the surface morphology and structural properties of the catalyst. Using H2-TPR, the reduction characteristics of the produced samples were investigated. This was performed at an AutoChem1 Ⅱ2920 fitted with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). It was usually necessary to pretreat the samples (about 150 mg) for two hours at 300 °C while argon was flowing. Following a cooling to 50 °C, the samples were heated in a 10 % H2 flow at a rate of 5 °C/min while maintaining an Ar balance. The CO2-TPD experiment was used to examine the basicity of samples. To measure CO2-TPD, a 0.1 g sample was first reduced for 2 h at 300 °C. Following a 50 °C cooling period, the sample was saturated with 10 vol % CO2/N2 (25 mL/min) for adsorption for 0.5 h. After that, it was flushed for a further 0.5 h with He (30 mL/min). Then, the CO2-TPD experiment was run under He at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Kratos XSAM800 spectrometer was used to measure XPS, and Al Kα rays were used to analyze the elements in the samples. The element content in the catalyst was determined by ICP-OES. The DCu (Cu dispersion), SCu(Cu specific surface area) and dCu(Cu particle size) were determined by the N2O-TPR method. Generally, N2 flow pretreatment was applied to 100 mg samples for 1 hour at 300 °C, and the samples were cooled to 50 °C. The samples were then heated to 300 °C. Subsequently, the samples underwent a reduction process using 10 vol% H2/N2 at 300 °C for a duration of 1 hour. The associated H2 consumption was reported as X. The reduced samples were subsequently subjected for one hour at 60 °C to 2 vol% N2O/He, guaranteeing that the surface metal Cu had fully oxidized to Cu2O. The samples were then cooled to room temperature and subjected to another 30-minute N2 purge. The sample was then ramped up to 300 °C ramping at the same temperature, where Y represents the amount of H2 used. The following formulas were used to determine the DCu, SCu, and dCu: (1) D C u = 2 Y X × 100 % (2) S C u = 2 Y × N 1.4 × 10 19 × W × X (3) d C u = 1.1 D C u where N represents the Avogadro constant (6.02 × 1023 atom/mol), and W represents the atomic mass of copper (63.546 g/mol). Using an MCT detector, in situ DRIFTS data was captured on the Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. The material was in situ decreased at 300 °C H2 for one hour. The sample was reduced in situ at 300 °C H2 (20 mL/min) for one hour for CO adsorption analysis. It was then scanned in Ar for thirty minutes, and it was cooled to room temperature for thirty minutes of CO adsorption. The spectrum was then gathered after 30 min of further Ar scanning to remove the adsorbed CO material. The adsorption temperature was adjusted to 240 °C because the catalyst exhibited better catalytic activity at this temperature. The CO2 adsorption FTIR spectroscopy experimental procedure was identical to the CO adsorption. For the purpose of obtaining the background spectrum for in-situ FTIR spectroscopy, a one-hour in situ reduction of the catalyst at H2 (20 mL/min) at 300 °C was done. After that, it was purged with He for thirty minutes to eliminate any physically bound H2, and it was cooled to 240 °C to collect data. Ultimately, He was swapped out for a combination of raw materials (CO2:H2:N2=24:72:4), and an infrared spectrum with a resolution of 4 cm−1 was acquired. Additionally, the process of the intermediate product altering over time was recorded. 2.3 Reaction performance evaluation A high-pressure fixed-bed reactor was used to synthesize methanol by CO2 hydrogenation. 2.0 g of quartz sand and 0.5 g of catalyst (both 20–40 mesh) were added to a reactor tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm prior to the CO2 hydrogenation process to methanol. Initially, H2 (50 ml/min) was used to reduce the catalyst for 4 h at 300 °C. After cooling the reactor to 200 °C, the feed gas (24 % CO2, 72 % H2, and 4 % N2) was added to the pressurized reactor, which was compressed to 2.5 MPa. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of feed gas set to 9000 mL⋅gcat −1⋅h − 1. The definitions of the CO2 conversion rate (XCO2), CH3OH selectivity (SCH3OH), and space-time yields of CH3OH (STYCH3OH, g⋅kgcat −1h−1) were as follows: (4) X C O 2 = [ C O 2 ] i n − [ C O 2 ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n × 100 % (5) S C H 3 O H = [ C H 3 O H ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n − [ C O 2 ] o u t × 100 % (6) S T Y C H 3 O H = F C O 2 , i n × X C O 2 × S C H 3 O H × M C H 3 O H W c a t Where, [CO2]in and [CO2]out represent the input and output of carbon dioxide (mol), [CH3OH]out represents the output of methanol (mol), FCO2,in represents the molar input flow of carbon dioxide(mol⋅h−1), and Wcat represents the mass of catalyst (g). MCH3OH represents the molar mass of methanol (g⋅mol−1). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural characterization of the catalysts The crystallinity of the phases was determined using XRD to characterize the x-CMA catalysts. Fig. 1 a showed the XRD patterns of the x-CMA catalyst precursors. The X-ray characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=11.3 °, 22.7 °, 34.7 °, 38.9 °, 45.4 °, 60.5 ° and 61.6 ° were attributed to the crystal planes of Mg-Al hydrotalcite structure (JCPDS35–0965), indicating that the hydrotalcite structure was formed successfully in the x-CMA catalyst precursors [40]. The XRD patterns of x-CMA catalysts after calcination at 500 °C were shown in Fig. 1 b. After the calcination of precursors, the hydrotalcite structure disappeared in the XRD patterns, which proved that the hydrotalcite structure was destroyed by high-temperature calcination. The X-ray characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=36.5 °, 43.1 °, 62.7 °, and 78.9 ° corresponds to the (111), (200), (220), and (222) crystal planes belong to MgO [41], respectively, which become the main crystalline phases for x-CMA catalysts. There were no obvious characteristic peaks linked to CuO, CuAl2O4 spinel, or Al2O3, which suggested that CuO had high dispersion on support when Cu loading was low [42]. But when Cu loading increased, the XRD pattern of 12-CMA showed a diffraction peak of CuO, which was most likely the result of agglomeration of CuO particles in the catalyst as a result of a high Cu content [43]. Fig. 2 displayed N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and the pore size distribution of the x-CMA catalysts. All samples possessed normal type IV adsorption isotherms with distinct hysteresis curves, as shown in Fig. 2 a, suggesting that the mesoporous structure of the x-CMA catalysts was typical [44]. All the x-CMA samples had an H3 hysteresis loop, except for the 12-CMA sample, which displayed an H2 hysteresis loop instead [45]. The textural characteristics of x-CMA catalysts (Table 1 ) and the pore size distribution diagram (Fig. 2 b) showed that all samples had pores between 2 and 40 nm, which were mesoporous structures created by the accumulation of nanoparticles. The BET surface area of the x-CMA catalysts decreased with a rise in Cu loading in the range of 177.4–156.2 m2•g−1, which was smaller than that of the MA sample (203.4 m2•g−1). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to observe the morphology of CuMgAl-x catalysts after reduction, the results were displayed in Fig. 3 . According to the TEM image and Cu particle size distribution of x-CMA (Fig. 3 and Table 1), it can be found that when the Cu loading increased from 4 wt% to 12 wt%, the dispersion of Cu particles decreased from 38.4 % to 20.4 %, and the size of Cu particles increases from 3.67 nm to 6.42 nm. The lattice with a spacing of 0.207 nm, which matched the (111) plane of metal Cu, and the lattice with a spacing of 0.220 nm, which matched the (200) plane of MgO, were both clearly visible in the HRTEM image. Additionally, a distinct interface between the metal Cu and MgO was discovered (Fig. 3 f). No lattice of Al2O3 was found because Al2O3 existed in an amorphous form, which was consistent with the description of XRD(Fig. 1 b). Although no Al2O3 was detected, it has been proved that Al2O3 has a positive effect on the anti-sintering of the catalyst in the catalytic process [46–48]. We additionally displayed the EDX element mappings of 10-CMA in Fig. 3 g to aid in a clearer analysis of the structure and composition of the catalyst. The element mapping made it abundantly evident that Cu, Mg, and Al were distributed uniformly and did not aggregate, which was favorable for the generation of the Cu-MgO interface [46]. The H2-TPR experiment is a crucial tool for assessing MSI on catalysts. The reduction of CuO species was shown by the peaks between 130 °C and 350 °C in the H2-TPR curves of the x-CMA catalysts shown in Fig. 4 a. In H2-TPR experiment, two hydrogen consumption peaks were seen (Fig. 4 a-b). The reduction of CuO with great dispersion on the catalyst surface was associated with the α peak at low temperature, and the reduction of bulk CuO was linked to the β peak at high temperature [47]. It can be found that the reduction peak first moved to low temperature and then moved to high temperature with the increase of Cu loading. When the Cu loading was low (4 wt%), there was a strong interaction between Cu and the support so the reduction temperature was in the high temperature region. When the Cu loading was high (12 wt%), the high Cu loading led to the formation of more bulk CuO, which was not conducive to the reduction of CuO, resulting in the reduction temperature moving to high temperature. When the loading of Cu was 10 wt%, the appropriate interaction between Cu and support was conducive to the formation of more highly dispersed CuO, which reduced the reduction difficulty of CuO and promoted the formation of more Cu-MgO interfaces. The basic properties played a very important role in the process of carbon dioxide adsorption and conversion. CO2-TPD was used to characterize the basic properties of the x-CMA catalysts, and the results were displayed in Fig. 5 a-b. Three Gaussian peaks may be identified in the desorption curves of all catalysts. Peak α (110–220 °C) can be attributed to CO2 desorption at weakly alkaline sites associated with surface hydroxyl groups, peak β (230–390 °C) is related to CO2 desorption at medium alkaline sites on the metal-support interfaces, and peak γ (400–500 °C) is attributed to CO2 desorption at strongly alkaline sites associated with coordinatively unsaturated O2 species [48,49]. It can be seen from Fig. 5 that the MSI effect regulated the CO2 adsorption capacity of x-CMA catalysts. The peak area of each CO2 resolving peak fluctuated with the Cu loading in a volcanic manner. Among them, the contribution of β peak to CO2 adsorption was the largest. When the Cu loading was 10 wt%, the maximum β peak area was obtained, which meant that the largest Cu-MgO interfaces existed on the 10-CMA catalyst. Compared with 10-C/MA, the β peak area of 10-CMA was larger, which further confirmed that more Cu-MgO interfaces had stronger adsorption capacity for CO2. The H2-TPD profile (Fig. 6 a-b) showed two peaks that were caused by the various adsorption states of hydrogen component on the reduction catalyst surface. Atomic hydrogen on Cu0 desorbs to form the desorption peak (α) at approximately 100 °C, whereas hydrogen on the surface of MgO produces the peak (β) at approximately 430 °C [50]. It was noteworthy that the α peak area in H2-TPD on the x-CMA catalyst had a comparable pattern to the α peak area in H2-TPR (Fig. 4). Owing to the increased surface-exposed copper area, 10-CZA catalysts exhibited the biggest area for the α peak [51]. Furthermore, the area of the β peak also gradually diminished as Cu loading increased, maybe because of a reduction of the hydrogen spillover effect and a decrease in Cu dispersion (Table 1). These findings demonstrated the significant reliance of H2 adsorption capability on the Cu-MgO interaction. To find out more about the significant impact of the Cu state on the catalyst surface on the catalytic behavior, XPS analysis of every catalyst was performed. Fig. 7 showed the XPS spectra of all x-CMA catalysts following reduction. The reduced Cu0/Cu+ was represented by the characteristic peaks at 932.9 and 952.6 eV in the Cu 2p spectrum (Fig. 7 a), whereas the Cu2+ species was represented by the characteristic peaks at 934.8 and 954.7 eV [52]. In order to further confirm the Cu-MgO interface, the LMM auger spectrum of Cu was performed on the reduced x-CMA catalyst. As can be seen from Fig. S1, the LMM auger spectrum of Cu was deconvolved into two peaks at 918.6 eV and 913.1 eV, which can be attributed to Cu0 and Cu+, respectively [53]. The 10-CMA catalyst had the highest content of Cu0, which was conducive to the generation of Cu-MgO interface. With the increase of Cu loading, the peak positions of Mg 2p and Al 2p remained basically unchanged, and O1s gradually moved towards the direction of low binding energy, indicating the existence of electron transfer at the Cu-MgO interface [54]. As shown in Fig. S2, 10-CMA had more Cu° content than 10-C/MA, indicating that more Cu-MgO interfaces were formed on 10-CMA, which was consistent with the characterization results of CO2-TPD. Three separate peaks at 530.6, 531.9, and 532.9 eV can be seen among the distinctive peaks of the O 1 s area [55,56], as depicted in Fig. 7 d. These peaks were responsible for oxygen in hydroxyl groups (OH), oxygen vacancies (OV), and surface lattice oxygen (OL), respectively [57]. It can be seen from Fig. 7 d that 10-CMA had the most oxygen vacancies, which may be related to the most Cu-MgO interfaces on 10-CMA. 3.2 Catalytic activity tests The CO2 hydrogenation activity of the x-CMA catalyst to methanol with varying Cu loading was displayed in Fig. 8 a. As the Cu loading rose, the activity of catalysts showed a volcano trend. The most appropriate catalyst had the Cu loading of 10 wt.%, as evidenced by the CO2 conversion rate of 10-CMA of up to 14.1 %, methanol selectivity of up to 93.9 %, and methanol production of up to 408.6 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1. Further analysis of the catalytic efficacy of 10-CMA catalyst and contrasting its response to varying temperatures with that of the 10-C/MA catalyst made via the impregnation process (Fig. 8 b). The carbon dioxide hydrogenation activity of the x-CMA catalyst to methanol at varying Cu loading was demonstrated in Fig. 8a. With the increase of Cu loading, the activity of the catalyst showed a volcanic trend. The CO2 conversion rate of 10-CMA was up to 14.1 %, the methanol selectivity was up to 93.9 %, and the methanol yield was up to 408.6 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1. In order to further analyze the effect of high Cu loading on catalyst performance, the Cu loading on 10-CMA catalyst was increased to 20 wt% and 30 wt% respectively, and the results were shown in Fig. S3. When the Cu loading on the 10-CMA catalyst increased from 10 wt% to 20 wt% and 30 wt%, the CO2 conversion rate decreased from 14.1 % to 11.2 % and 7.7 %, and the selectivity of methanol decreased from 93.9 % to 84.1 % and 71.3 %, respectively. The yield of methanol decreased from 408.6 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1 to 290.7 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1 and 169.4 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1, respectively, suggesting that the most appropriate catalyst had the Cu loading of 10 wt%. In order to further analyze the catalytic performance of the 10-CMA catalyst, studies were conducted to determine how various temperatures affected the catalytic performance and compared with the 10-C/MA catalyst (Fig. 8 b). As the reaction temperature rose for the 10-CMA catalyst, the amount of CO2 converted also rose, suggesting that high temperatures was favorable for CO2 activation and conversion. On the other hand, in opposition to the shifting trend of CO2 conversion, the selectivity of CH3OH diminished with rising temperatures. The process that hydrogenation carbon dioxide into methanol actually involved two significant competing processes. Two processes were known as the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction and methanol synthesis, respectively [58,59]. The following described the equilibrium of these reactions: (7) C O 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ C H 3 OH + H 2 O ▵ H = − 49.5 kJmo l − 1 (8) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ▵ H = + 41.2 kJmo l − 1 The production of methanol was an exothermic, reversible reaction, as demonstrated by reaction (7), and as reaction temperature increased, so did the equilibrium constant. Furthermore, the apparent activation energy of the methanol synthesis reaction was lower than that of the RWGS reaction (8). As a result, as reaction temperature increased over the complete temperature range, the selectivity of CH3OH dropped. 10-CMA outperformed 10-C/MA in Carbon dioxide catalytic properties, and its methanol yield was 1.55 times that of 10-C/MA (263.1 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1). This is because an appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO on the 10-CMA catalyst was conducive to the generation of more Cu-MgO interfaces, and enhanced the dissociation of H2 and the adsorption of CO2, which was conducive to the formation of methanol. As illustrated in Fig. 8 c, the TOF value of the catalyst presented a volcanic change with temperature. At 240 °C, 10-CMA had the largest TOF value (9.01×10−3 s−1), which was 1.55 times that of 10-C/MA (6.82×10−3 s−1). Obviously, 10-CMA was the catalyst with higher methanol production efficiency. GHSV plays an important role in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The catalytic performance of 10-CMA catalyst at 4000–10000 h−1 was investigated, and the results were shown in Fig. S4. When the GHSV was 4000 h−1, the 10-CMA catalyst exhibited the highest CO2 conversion and the lowest CH3OH selectivity. Low GHSV meant that the contact time between reaction gas and catalyst surface was long, which made more CO2 molecules participate in methanol synthesis reaction. Conversely, longer contact time may cause the decomposition of CH3OH. With the increase of GHSV, the conversion of CO2 decreased slightly. However, when GHSV was higher than 9000 h−1, the selectivity of CH3OH did not change significantly. STY of 10-CMA catalyst increased with the increase of GHSV except at 10000 h−1, which was due to more feedstock entering the reactor to participate in the reaction. Long cycle testing of catalysts is one of the important indexes for evaluating catalyst performance. Fig. 8 d illustrated the catalytic performance varies of 10-CMA over time. The active sites of 10-CMA catalyst remained robust during the 150-hour catalysis test, as evidenced by the good stability of both carbon dioxide conversion and methanol selectivity. Both fresh and spent 10-CMA catalyst were subjected to XRD characterization, as illustrated in Fig. S5. The XRD pattern of the spent-10-CMA catalyst was found to be identical to that of the fresh-10-CMA catalyst. Additionally, and no obvious characteristic peak of metal Cu was found, indicating that Cu particles were well dispersed after the reaction. As demonstrated in Fig. S6, the TEM characterization of the spent 10-CMA catalyst revealed that there was no obvious sintering and that the Cu particle size after the reaction (5.95 nm) was slightly larger than that before the reaction (4.34 nm), suggesting that the Cu particles in the 10-CMA catalyst still had good dispersion after the reaction. As demonstrated by the aforementioned findings, appropriate Cu loadings enhanced the catalytic efficacy of x-CMA throughout the CO2 hydrogenation process, leading to methanol production. For CO2 adsorption and H2 activation, an appropriate Cu-MgO interaction was seen when Cu loading was 10 wt.%. In order to examine the structure-activity connection of the x-CMA catalyst in more detail, the effects of CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation on methanol yield were investigated. The yield of methanol was found to have a linearly positive correlation with the amount of H2 desorption, as shown in Fig. 9 a. This suggested that the amount of H2 desorption was a critical factor in the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation process that ultimately produces methanol [60]. Fig. 9 b illustrated how the amount of CO2 desorption contributed positively to the creation of methanol. Although the correlation coefficient between CO2 desorption and STYCH3OH methanol (R2=0.86) was smaller than that between H2 desorption and STYCH3OH (R2=0.95), the adsorption capacity of catalyst for CO2 was one of the evaluation indexes of high-performance catalyst [61]. Among all catalysts, 10-CMA exhibited the best H2 dissociation capacity and CO2 adsorption capacity, which was the reason why it had the best catalytic performance. To further examine the catalytic performance of 10-CMA catalyst more detail, it was contrasted with a few common catalysts for the hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to methanol reaction. Table S1 listed a range of operating parameters and corresponding catalytic performance data for each catalyst. Some traditional Cu-based catalysts [60,62–64] and the catalysts comprising both Mg and Al components simultaneously [9,22,26] performed less well catalytically than the 10-CMA catalyst. But, the STYCH3OH was higher for GaZnZrOx [65] and Pd/In2O3-ZrO2 [66] than it was for 10-CMA, mostly due to the activity tests of the catalysts being conducted at higher GHSV, pressure, or temperature. Higher STYCH3OH can be produced as a result of a notable increase in the GHSV, which mainly because the activity tests of these catalysts were performed at higher GHSV, pressure, or temperature. In particular, the increase in the GHSV can significantly increase the methanol production capacity, resulting in higher STYCH3OH. In summary, 10-CMA has excellent catalytic performance with the advantages of low cost, green environmental protection, and easy industrial production, so it can be used as an ideal catalyst for methanol synthesis. 3.3 Reaction pathway and structure-performance relationship To more easily monitor the evolution of intermediate species, in situ DRIFT spectra were recorded during the carbon dioxide adsorption process on the reduced 10-CMA and 10-C/MA catalysts. Strong bands occurred at 1644, 1538, and 1428 cm−1, corresponding to the characteristic peaks of bicarbonate (HCO3*) and carbonate (CO3*), respectively, after the catalysts were exposed to CO2, as illustrated in Fig. S7. Adsorption occurred at weak and strong basic sites on the catalysts, producing HCO3* and CO3*, respectively [57]. Fig. S7 showed that 10-CMA had higher HCO3* and CO3* adsorption peak strengths than 10-C/MA. This suggested that the 10-CMA with more Cu-MgO interfaces had a higher capacity for CO2 adsorption, which was in line with the CO2-TPD results (Fig. 5). In order to study the conversion of intermediate products to methanol after CO2 adsorption, the system was cleaned with N2 and then hydrogen was injected for the hydrogenation reaction. The transformation characteristics of the key intermediate products during the hydrogenation of these catalysts at 40–320 °C were displayed in Fig. 10 . For the 10-CMA catalyst (Fig. 10a), three characteristic peaks were found at 1644,1538, and 1428 cm−1 were attributed to HCO3* and CO3* at 40 °C, and no other characteristic peaks were found at this temperature. The typical peak intensities of HCO3* and CO3* steadily declined as the temperature increased to 120 °C, while the characteristic peak intensities of HCOO* gradually increased, suggesting that HCO3* and CO3* converted to HCOO* [67,68]. The characteristic peak intensity of formate increased rapidly with temperature, but the methoxy group (CH3O*) signal did not emerge until 160 °C. Formamate (HCOO*) was encouraged to convert to CH3O* material when the temperature progressively increased to 240 °C, which was characterized by a gradually stronger signal of CH3O* and a gradually weaker band of HCOO*. With a rose in temperature, the 10-C/MA catalyst (Fig. 10b) continued to show the conversion of CO3* species to HCOO* species, but the signal strength of the CH3O* group on 10-C/MA was significantly weaker than that on 10-CMA, which was consistent with more CO3* accumulation on 10-C/MA. At the same time, compared with the 10-CMA catalyst, it was found that the strength of bicarbonate (HCO3*) reached the maximum when the temperature rose to 120 °C, but there was no obvious change in strength when the temperature continued to rise, indicating that the ability of HCO3* to convert into HCOO* on 10-C/MA was weaker than 10-CMA [29]. The H2-TPD results showed that 10-CMA had a stronger H2 desorption peak at low temperatures than 10-C/MA. This suggested that 10-CMA had a better capacity for H2 activation because of an appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO, which made it more likely for highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles to form and encourage H2 dissociation, which in turn encourages the hydrogenation conversion of intermediate species CO3* and HCO3-to HCOO*, and the futher conversion from HCOO* to CH3O*. From the previous discussion, it was clear that the catalytic hydrogenation reaction of CO2 to methanol synthesis was greatly aided by the interaction between active Cu and MgO on the 10-CMA catalyst. By modifying the Cu loading and preparation technique, the most Cu-MgO interfaces can be shown on the 10-CMA catalyst, yielding the optimum performance of methanol production. Fig. 11 described the reaction pathway comparison of x-CMA catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol before and after the optimization of Cu-MgO interaction. In this work, the diversity of basic sites on the x-CMA catalysts was influenced by the MSI. An appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO on 10-CMA catalyst was conducive to the generation of Cu-MgO interface, and promoted the adsorption of CO2, enhancing its subsequent conversion into CO3* and HCO3* intermediate species. The suitable MSI on the 10-CMA catalyst was conducive to the formation of Cu0, made H2 more easily dissociated, facilitated the rapid conversion of CO3* and HCO3* to HCOO*, and promoted the further conversion of HCOO* to CH3O* and CH3OH. 4 Conclusions In summary, the co-precipitation approach was used to prepare a series of x-CMA catalysts using hydrotalcite as the precursor. Comprehensive research was done on the impact of Cu loading on the efficiency in methanol production. The Cu loading had great influence on the Cu-MgO interaction on the x-CMA catalyst, the 10-CMA catalyst exhibited the most Cu-MgO interfaces by appropriate Cu-MgO interaction among all catalysts, which promoted the adsorption of CO2. An appropriate Cu-MgO interaction was conducive to the dissociation of H2, which accelerated the process of turning important intermediate species into methanol. The 10-CMA obtained by the coprecipitation approach had more Cu-MgO interfaces than the 10-C/MA prepared by the impregnation method, 10-CMA showed better catalytic performance. At 240 °C and 2.5 MPa, the 10-CMA catalyst demonstrated optimum performance in generating methanol, as evidenced by its XCO2 of 14.1 %, SCH3OH of 93.9 %, and STYCH3OH of 408.6 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h−1. Eq. coredata.dc:description: Using the coprecipitation approach, the CuMgAl catalysts with varying Cu loadings (x-CMA, x = 4, 6, 8, 10, 12 wt.%) were created from hydrotalcite precursors and used in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol process. In this work, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, TEM, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, H2-TPD, XPS, and in situ DRIFTS characterization techniques were used to examine the structure and surface characteristics of x-CMA catalysts. The results demonstrated that an appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO was formed when the Cu loading was 10 wt%, which was conducive to the generation of more Cu-MgO interfaces, boosting the adsorption of CO2. The appropriate interaction between Cu and MgO also facilitates the production of Cu0, enhancing the dissociation of H2. The conversion of CO3 * and HCO3 * to HCOO * has been sped up by advancements in CO2 adsorption and H2 dissociation, which made the subsequent conversion to CH3OH easier. It also be found that 10-CMA obtained by the coprecipitation approach exhibited more Cu-MgO interfaces than 10-C/MA prepared by the impregnation method. At 2.5 MPa and 240 °C, the 10-CMA catalyst had the maximum STYCH3OH of 408.6 g⋅kgcat. −1⋅h −1 with the XCO2 of 14.1 % and SCH 3 OH of 93.9 %. The findings presented in this work may offer a fresh perspective on how to create high-efficiency catalysts that hydrogenate CO2 into methanol.
coredata.dc:title: High-performance CuMgAl catalysts derived from hydrotalcite for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol: Effects of Cu-MgO interaction
